description: From Middle English blocker, blokker, bloker, blokkere, equivalent to block +‎ -er.

definitionGroups.group: Agent noun of block (“obstruct or prevent”); something that blocks something else.

entries.meaning: (sports) One who blocks or impedes the movement of an opponent.
(computing) One who prevents another user from contacting them electronically.
examples: Likewise, any connections shared between your child (the blocker) and the user being blocked will also be broken.

entries.meaning: (computing) An application that stops / impedes unauthorised access to a programme.
(computing) A bug or issue that prevents software from being released.
(marketing) A gatekeeper who refuses the marketer access to the person they wish to contact.
examples: Sometimes your sales progress skids to a halt. We've all met more blockers than we'd care to. Some are assigned by the company to filter services  […]

entries.meaning: (biology, medicine) Any of various medications that block (inhibit) the activity of a chemical messenger or its receptors, such as cardiac conduction modifiers (e.g., alpha-blockers), gastric acid inhibitors (H₂ histamine blockers), puberty blockers, and others.
A close-fitting rectangular glove worn by a goalie in multiple forms of hockey.
(card games) A playing card, needed by one player, that is held by another.
A person who blocks (stretches or moulds) hats.
examples: Because in 1937 Benjamin is still an apprentice, he remains bound to the Eastern Finland Hat Factory.  […]  Benjamin now does much of the same work as the master cutters and blockers and enjoys their grudging approval of his skills.
